block.p: A review of New York books on Dec. 31, in appraising ''Water-Works: The Architecture and Engineering of the New York City Water Supply,'' referred incorrectly to the origin of the octagonal logo used by JPMorgan Chase & Company. Ivan Chermayeff, who designed the logo with Tom Geismar, said the design was intended to be distinctive and geometric; he said the design was not related to a New York water provider that was the forerunner to JPMorgan Chase & Company. The logo was not intended to resemble a cross-section of a wooden water pipe, and any such resemblance was not the decisive factor in the selection of the logo from several proposed designs.

A review of New York books on Dec. 31, in appraising ''Water-Works: The Architecture and Engineering of the New York City Water Supply,'' referred incorrectly to the origin of the octagonal logo used by JPMorgan Chase & Company. Ivan Chermayeff, who designed the logo with Tom Geismar, said the design was intended to be distinctive and geometric; he said the design was not related to a New York water provider that was the forerunner to JPMorgan Chase & Company. The logo was not intended to resemble a cross-section of a wooden water pipe, and any such resemblance was not the decisive factor in the selection of the logo from several proposed designs.
